ext_descriptions.ext_description:
this provides a numerical definition of a probability distribution as a list of random_variable/function_value pairs.
Distribution_by_value is used where there is no named distribution which can be used to identify the distribution, for example, when the distribution is derived from observation.

this identifies the type of function which the random_variable/function_value list represents.
Probabilities may be described by a number of different types of functions, such as the cumulative distribution function, the probability density function for continuous distributions or the probability generation function for discrete distributions. Each function is identified through reference data.

this is a list of random_variable/function_value pairs, where the value of random variable increases strictly monotonically along the list. It represents a numerical approximation to a probability distribution. The distribution is the probability generating function for an unfair dice ((1,0.1), (2,0.166),...,(6,0.23)). Here each pair represents the value on the face and the probability of it occuring. The probability of rolling a 1 or a 2 is therefore (0.1 + 0.166). The distribution is a cumulative distribution function for the measured length of a component ((2.1, 0.0), (2.2, 0.1), (2.3, 0.6), (2.4, 1.0)) Here each pair represents a length and the probability that the component exceeds that length. The probability that the component is between 2.2m and 2.3m long is therefore 0.5 (0.6 - 0.1). The term "random variable" is used to denote the quantity observed to vary randomly, such as the number of heads in a coin tossing experiment, or the observed length of a component.

The function_value_pair holds a single random_variable/value pair, so defining a single point on the distribution curve of a numerically defined distribution. The distribution function for the tossing of two coins uses the number of heads as the index and the probability as actual_value, and has the form of a list of three pairs ((0, 0.25), (1, 0.5), (2, 0.25)) - 0, 1 and 2 being the random variable values, 0.25, 0.5 and 0.25 being the probability values.
the value of the probability function for the given random variable value
the value of the random variable

A Parameter provides on of the set of values that characterises a probability distribution. The Normal (or Gaussian) distribution has, in the standard parameterisation, two parameters: the mean and the variance For many common distributions, the mean and the variance are sufficient to characterise a distribution, and the parameter list may be empty. Probability_distribution_parameter inherits the 'name' attribute from its supertype, and this is used to identify the name of the parameter within the particular parameterization. The value attribute is also inherited.

Parameterized_distribution is used to link a named probability distribution to the parameters that define it. The paramterization_name of this entity is used to discriminate between alternative parameterizations of the same distribution. To calculate a value using a paramaterized_distribution it is necessary to know the general distribution function, the value of the distribution function parameters, and the specific random variable value for which the probability evaluation is required. The Probability Distribution module does not define the formula for the distribution function, and it is assumed that this is defined externally, either through reference information or via a "formula" module. This entity provides the distribution function parameters. The value of the random variable for which the probability is calculated is provided by the in the Probability module (see note 2)
.

the list of parameters used in the parameterization. In many distributions there is a trivial relationship between the mean and variance for the distribution. In such a case it is not necessary to list the parameters.
the name of the parameterization, distinguishing it from other parameterizations.

A probability distribution relates all possible outcomes of an observation on a given system with the probability of their occuring. For a full understanding of probability distribution and the terms used, a textbook on probability theory should be consulted. This entity describes a particular probability distribution, rather than the general type of distribution. For example, in coin tossing experiment, the number of heads that may occur is given by a binomial distribution - that is, a type of distribution, and outside the scope of this module. This module provides the discription of the distribution of a particular experiment, say, 10 tosses of a particular coin. The actual probability of an outcome, say 6 heads in 10 tosses, is recorded using the probability module.
The attributes 'name', 'id' and 'description' are inherited from the supertype . The name provides a cue to the particular source of the distribution, such as "A fair coin tossed 10 times", rather than the type of distribution (in this case Binomial) which is given by the distribution_name attribute.

the name of the type of distribution that the distribution is taken from. The name is taken from reference data, which is based on the standard mathematical names for distributions, such as "Binomial", "Normal", "Guassian". Empirically derived distributions will not normally be named.

this is used to distinguish continous distributions from discrete distributions. The measurement of a persons height is a continuous distribution, since it can take any value between 0 and 3m. Coin tossing gives rise to a discrete distribution, since the number of heads cannot be a fraction.
the mean is a mathematical property of a probability distribution, and this attribute holds the value for the distribution.
the variance is a mathematical property of a probability distribution, and this attribute holds the value for the distribution.

The value of the probability function at the given random variable value. The value is an inherited attribute. It is not in general a probability value. In some functions for continuous distributions, the probability that the random variable lies between two values is the integral of the function of that range.
The value of a random variable. The value attribute is inherited from the supertype.
The numerically defined function that describes the distribution function.
a single random_variable/function_value point on the function
